body:
I think the test is incorrect but simplification may be correct (since it compares values of the operator).
`a < 3 and a < 4` reduced to `a < 3`

Here is example of the test (mongo adapter). [testFilterRedundant()](https://github.com/apache/calcite/blob/master/mongodb/src/test/java/org/apache/calcite/adapter/mongodb/MongoAdapterTest.java#L281)

[stronger()](https://github.com/apache/calcite/blob/master/mongodb/src/main/java/org/apache/calcite/adapter/mongodb/MongoFilter.java#L147) for simplification code.

From comments it seems that mongo didn't like having multiple operators on the same attribute (maybe this has changed in the last versions). It is not an issue in Elastic.

My original statement that values of operator don't matter was indeed incorrect and maybe there is a bug in simplification itself. 

But the idea  is to reduce `>` and `<`  (not `=`). From what I understand
` a > 1 and a > 2` simplified to `a > 2`
` a < 1 and a < 2` simplified to `a < 1`

@snuyanzin, thanks for update, I think with this approach field `SRC_DIR` and local variable `file` may be removed and instead of passing `file.getAbsolutePath()` may be passed some string literal.
Also, since writer is declared using try with resources, no need to close it manually.

@vvysotskyi agree, thank you!
I have just updated PR based on your comments

@michaelmior I have added more tests to show that new `QueryBuilder` constructs correct ES queries (see for eg. [BooleanLogicTest](https://github.com/asereda-gs/calcite/blob/6c4189e6bdea/elasticsearch/src/test/java/org/apache/calcite/adapter/elasticsearch/BooleanLogicTest.java#L116)). I'm not sure why previous simplification(s) were done that way (they share same ideas with Mongo adapter).

Please let me know if you have more questions.

you probably want to squeeze the commit into one.
also create/link JIRA for this
looks good.
Overall LGTM. Can you rename `RelToSqlNestedStruct` to `RelToSqlNestedStructTest`? It would also probably be a good idea to validate the result of `RelToSqlConverter`.

Hello @michaelmior, thanks for the feedback :)
I renamed the test class and updated the test case to assert the validity of the sql string.

Hi @BenoitHanotte, for creating appropriate tests I believe you can add a few test methods in `RelToSqlConverterTest`. A schema with some minimal nesting that may be sufficient for your case exists in `CalciteAssert.SchemaSpec.HR`. 

If you need a Schema with more nesting in order to test your feature wait for [PR762](https://github.com/apache/calcite/pull/762).

Thanks @zabetak , indeed the `depts` table has a nested struct that allows testing this fix with a much reduced boiler plate. 
I updated my PR to add a test case to `RelToSqlConverterTest` and remove the `RelToSqlConverterNestedStructsTest` file, it is much cleaner this way :)

Unfortunately I discovered that this fix is not giving correct names for the nested fields:
```
SELECT * FROM depts
```
gives the following query:
```
SELECT deptno, name, employees, location, location AS location FROM hr.depts
```
I'll have alook at it this afternoon but from my limited understanding of the code, we'll have to make sure that `RexFieldAccess` is actually going through the correlation path to keep track of the reference
Does `mvn apache-rat:check` check passes for this PR?

@vvysotskyi Good catch. This was of course failing because of the lack of license in the CQL file. I'm checking what the upstream license is and assuming that it's not a problem, I'll add the license header.

@zabetak @michaelmior  I updated my PR, it seems that in addition to the cast issue we were not correctly mapping the field index to the `RelDataTypeField` of the row when the row type is nested.

For instance, for a `RecordType(INT a, RecordType(INT b)`, we need to build an ordered list such as
```
0: RelDataTypeField of a
1: RelDataTypeField of a.b
```
This way we can get the `RelDataTypeField` for given field index in an `AliasContext`

I added a few test cases to ensure that names were correctly retrieved for nested fields.

I updated the PR to do the following:
1. Support more than one level of RexFieldAccess (use a stack called `accesses` to store the `RexFieldAccess` levels, get the referenced `SqlNode`and then poll from the stack to add the name components)
2.  Add tests on a schema containing more than one level of nesting and more than one nested column

I haven't been able to find a more elegant solution to the correlation variable case as I don't seem to be able to get the field index without having access to the last level of `RexFieldAccess`, hence the inner switch case to handle this particular case.

I tested this patch on our production schema and it seems to have solved the issue.
Added a license for the CQL file so the RAT check is fine now.
Hello @michaelmior @zabetak would you have time for a review of this PR so that we can see whether this is the right approach or not? Thanks!
LGTM, merged! Sorry for the delay. I was waiting for the latest release to go through and this slipped off my radar. Thanks for the contribution :)
looks good from my side

No need to open a separate PR. There's still a few things to be fixed. Currently the dependency check fails on your branch after the import from `org.apache.cassandra`. I'll probably just ignore that warning since it's only used to fix a bug during testing. It also seems like the `cassandra.yaml` that was added is unnecessary. Tests pass for me without it. Can you confirm in IntelliJ?

I have fixed the dependency checks as well. All tests pass except JDK11. See [CASSANDRA-9608](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CASSANDRA-9608)

Without `cassandra.yaml` tests fail in IntelliJ. I think there is a different classpath for Eclipse / Maven and IntelliJ.

Do you want me to close this PR ?
No problem. Can you confirm that the cassandra.yaml isn't needed? Things seem to work fine for me without it and I'd rather not include it if not needed.
`cassandra.yaml` **is** required in IntelliJ 2018.2 (jdk10). Otherwise cluster can't initialize properly.
Okay, no problems here then. Feel free to merge this :) Thanks for the help!

Are you OK if these tests are skipped on JDK11 ? Last JDK11 is supported only by Cassandra 4.0+ (which is not released yet). For more details see [CASSANDRA-9608](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CASSANDRA-9608).
All tests pass now (JDK11 ignored). Feel free to use this commit commit or merge directly.
Great! Thanks again for the help :)
@vdiravka , #776 might be relevant as well.
@vlsi Does the test case from this PR pass with #776 changes?

This test verifies `OR(IS NOT NULL($0), IS NULL($0))`, and that optimization is out of scope of #776 yet.

However, I think the proper placement of that kind of test is `RexProgramTest`.

Doesn't fix things for me. But the failure I'm experiencing (which i think is the same as @julianhyde) is not intermittent and happens consistently. I haven't had any luck fixing it, but I know it happens during startup.
That said, thanks for this PR and it should still be merged.
Can you please describe the error in more details ? Stack trace, environment (OS, JDK, etc.)
@vlsi I've patched items from your review.
you may also want to squeeze the fix into 1 commit.
@ptrbojko , I have no clue if `validator.setIdentifierExpansion(true);` is a proper approach or not.

Thank u. I didnt get your point of covering SqlToRel conversion?
With what i did, we will have to iterate on SqlNodeList and convert each to Rel by calling each time SqlToRel.
You are proposing to enhance SqlToRel to skip that iteration from the caller side ?

What is your usecase?
Are you using only the SQLParser ?
Usually the Parser produces SqlNodes, then they are converted to RelNodes, then it comes the Planner.
Are you thinking abount the whole story or do you need only the parser stuff ?

For the moment, I am only interested in the parser stuff, and I am not closed to enhance it to the Rel conversion if needed. 
My use case is also as u describe, sql to rel through the planner. U are suggesting to convert the SqlNodeList into a list of RelNode in one call through the planner? Instead of iterating on the list and for each SqlNode calling the planner.convert ?
@vlsi Thanks for the review:) I've updated the code to address your comments.

@zuozhiw , what do you mean by `ascending/descending` order?

It looks like the tests overlap very much. Can you move common initialization code to `@Before` or something like that?

@vlsi `ascending/descending` is where the rule match is triggered - if it's triggered from a parent node, then match check is in in `descending` order: check the rule match from parent to its children. If it's triggered from a child node, then the check will be bottom-up, in `ascending` order.

Yes I agree that the two test cases overlap a lot. The second test case is built on top of the first one. I have merged them into one test case to avoid duplicate code, and added more comments.

@asereda-gs You can see my commit [here](https://github.com/michaelmior/calcite/commit/d1f21de944c93842c6203be1c5d5ba15739fe603). Feel free to just take those changes and apply where needed. I discovered when I couldn't reproduce the issue that it only applies to JDK versions with no dot in them, i.e. "10" instead of "10.0.0"
@michaelmior applied your patch to this PR. Thanks!
@michaelmior I have a counter-example to your assertion "it only applies to JDK versions with no dot in them". The test fails on OpenJDK 10.0.2.

@julianhyde We may be conflating two issues here: 
1) Wrong parsing of new [JDK version scheme](http://openjdk.java.net/jeps/223) (by calcite **and cassandra dependencies**). This is Mike's fix (d1f21de9).
2) Cassandra startup timeout on Linux Jenkins CI server. Contrary to github travis CI (the one which validates PRs), it takes about 20s for embedded cassandra to start. For now we have increased timeout to 30s in CassandraUnit (included in this PR). I will get back to you with more information about high startup times in Jenkins after investigation. 

When you say "The test fails on OpenJDK 10.0.2" do you mean (1) or (2) ?
Agreed that I think this PR and the associated JIRA are conflating two different issues, both relating to fixing problems with CassandraUnit. I'd suggest a rename to clarify.

I've squashed the commits.
I've removed unneeded (as for the fix sake) - validator.setIdentifierExpansion(true); . There are view expansion methods in calcite and this change was a little step to make them look similar. But this was no a part of a fix itself.
@vlsi  I've reused existing tbl function instead of creating new one. As desired.
@vlsi Thank you very much for the code review, I have patched my changes.

removed this stuff
> It extends standard SUM and COUNT functions to make it possible to do calls SUM(x, y), COUNT(x, y) where SUM(x, y) = SUM(x) filter (where x is not null) and the same for COUNT. 

In case of AggregateReduceFunctionsRule filters are used now. In case of window there is used old logic which look into all arguments if they are null or not and do aggregations only with non null [1]


[1] https://github.com/apache/calcite/blob/3c6b5ec759caadabb67f09d7a4963cc7d9386d0c/core/src/main/java/org/apache/calcite/adapter/enumerable/StrictAggImplementor.java#L154
I think this is feature complete. Could I get reviews please?

```
java.lang.ClassCastException: org.apache.calcite.util.NlsString cannot be cast to java.lang.Boolean
	at org.apache.calcite.test.RexProgramTest.testSimplifyCaseNullableBoolean(RexProgramTest.java:1573)
```

This was caused by copy-paste error. Now `testSimplifyCaseNullableBoolean` matches its previous code.

1. Made json/yaml mappers as final static
2. Corrected lattice related yaml in model.md
LGTM

Thank you for your review.

Changes in the commit [e9e5130](https://github.com/apache/calcite/pull/791/commits/e9e5130e8df9a2d760cf52d5ea0f31ae52edc5b5):
1. Added comment explaining usage of trim
2. Corrections of yaml models in examples/csv based on double check querying via sqlline
@vlsi Since you've looked at this as well, any further changes you think should be made before this is merged?

@michaelmior , English is far from being my native language, so I have no strong comments here.

I think it might make sense to add clarification for reviewers/committers (e.g. when to ask or not to ask the rebase, etc).

Just to clarify: I'm +1 re the current PR.

As usual, more things can be added later.
Thanks @zabetak and @vlsi! Merging for now and let's continue to iterate as needed.

Changes in commit 1c079c7 
Based on response in CALCITE-1026

2. Added tests checking if determination of JSON/YAML works correctly
3. Update documentation

I guess it could be squashed - will do it after
Merged in https://github.com/apache/calcite/commit/af3e35d64a7c29dfaa451c4ab4880424a8fe8cee

```
path = child.url().getPath();
```
which should be changed as well
Other than the minor grammar issue I pointed out, looks good to me :)
LGTM

A good start - thanks for contributing! Can you please log a JIRA case, and post a link to it here.

Also update the documentation, reference.md.

This function isn't standard SQL. What databases support this? Maybe OracleSqlOperatorTable is a better place for this to live.

@xcorail , that looks nice.

Just wondering, does LGTM integrate with GitHub checks?

Hi @vlsi 
LGTM integrates with the GitHub Pull Requests. Once you activate this integration on your project(s), LGTM will report any new problem or a fix of a problem directly within the pull request 
It's free and very simple to activate, give it a try [here](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/apache/calcite/ci/) and let me know!

@vlsi , as an example:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7395402/44846048-8c3cf880-ac4f-11e8-887b-cfc7328af1e6.png)

I meant something like https://developer.github.com/changes/2018-05-07-new-checks-api-public-beta/ 
It would be great if LGTM could add comments next to the changed lines (like a person would do).

Ha ok
Let me rephrase to make sure I get your point: 
At the moment, you'll get a report saying for example 1 new alert, and when you click on the report, it will open a LGTM window, and you'll see the LGTM comments next to the relevant changed lines but in this other window
With the GitHub check integration, you would see the LGTM comments directly in the native diff. 
It is interesting indeed, I will pass this idea to the team!

Hi @vlsi! Thanks for your suggestion. We're currently working on integrating the new GitHub Apps APIs into LGTM; we'll be working on the checks API after that. Give us a shout if you have any other suggestions/comments/questions!

@eolivelli , It adds no features, it removes no features, it fixes no bugs, that is why I assume existing tests (e.g. `org.apache.calcite.util.UtilTest#testNameSet` added by @julianhyde ) are just fine.
I change just implementation: Julian did craft floor/ceiling as a String (and there are exceptional characters), while I just add a custom class and teach comparator to recognize it.

Do you think tests are required?
If so, please suggest in plain what kind of tests are needed.

Well, it does fix a concurrency bug in NameHelper (by removing the class :) ), and the bug is easily reproducible in CI: https://builds.apache.org/job/Calcite-Master/807/jdk=JDK%2010%20(latest),label_exp=ubuntu&&!cloud-slave/console

```
SqlValidatorTest.testAmbiguousDynamicStar2:9875->SqlValidatorTestCase.checkEx:361
Expected error to have position, but actual error did not:  actual pos [line -1 col -1 thru line 100 col 99]
```

Hopefully after this PR gets merged the bug will go away.

LGTM. This has been very problematic for Beam. (See https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-4704) This is better then the current implementation where the extra characters are silently dropped, effectively resulting in silent data corruption. We'd like calcite's trim to behave like other SQL implementations (where multiple characters are all trimed), but that can be discussed in a followup.
Changes in this PR are already included in #822. If you merge that one, current review can be dropped.
Superseded by https://github.com/apache/calcite/pull/822
@michaelmior is there a way to close this PR?
Please also add the JIRA key CALCITE-2485 to the commit message
Closing this PR as #822 supersedes it.
@beikov For future reference, whoever opened the PR has to close it or it can be closed in a comment on another commit as usual. (I think we could also ask INFRA to do it, but not really worth it.)
Fixed in [this link](https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf?p=calcite.git;a=commit;h=23eb11eb3b59e496cdc865926537a76fff53c165). Close this PR.
Closed this as the discussion in JIRA.

well,It's a good idea.I will have a try.

Looks good to me. @pengzhiwei2018 , thanks for the code & extra tests.

There's an empty line at the end of `simplifyStrong` test though.
@vlsi Just to clarify 1 and 2 above are the first and second builds from a clean checkout?

> Just to clarify 1 and 2 above are the first and second builds from a clean checkout?

That's incremental builds. I just checkout different branches and all the target files and friends are kept there.

The only diff between branches is this PR

>Is there any way to drop the class at all?

Not before 2.0 release

This is all I have so far.

There might be glitches due to checkstyle failing here and there, however I do not intend to put more commits here.


The key question is "what is the way to merge this PR?"

Should it be "--no-ff"? (== should all the commits just land to master branch?) <-- I'm inclined to this approach.
Should it be a merge commit?
I assume I should not squash the commits, however I can do that if that is that is required.

Ok. Let me do the following: I squash all the changes (except the one with `[CALCITE-2561]`), however I do not update the PR.
Then PR enables to view individual changes, and the master history is "clean" somehow.

Ideas for "the commit message" are welcome.
